channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Anti-graft Center Displays Old Torture Techniques
item.description: The graphic exhibit, coming during President Xi Jinping’s campaign against corruption, showcases methods used in past eras, using life-size mock-ups of people being burned, cut and stretched.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Want to Touch a Dog? In Malaysia, It’s a Delicate Subject
item.description: The backlash by conservative Muslims over an attempt to widen appreciation of dogs has underlined the fault lines between Muslims and other groups in Malaysia.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Holding a dog at “I Want to Touch a Dog,” an event organized to help Malaysians break down perceptions of dogs.

item.title: Missiles of ISIS May Pose Peril for Aircrews
item.description: There is strong evidence that Islamic State fighters in Iraq are using advanced surface-to-air missile systems that pose a serious threat to aircraft.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Christians of Mosul Find Haven in Jordan
item.description: About 4,000 Christians left the Iraqi city of Mosul for Jordan in the last three months, forced out by Islamic State fighters.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: A Lebanese Battle With Syrian Overtones
item.description: Fighting raged between the Lebanese Army and Sunni militants in the northern city of Tripoli, which has been divided over the civil war in Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Lebanese soldiers raided an apartment in the northern city of Tripoli, where they have fought Sunni militants. Since Friday, 18 people have died.

item.title: Egyptian Media to Limit Criticism of Government
item.description: A group of Egyptian newspaper editors pledged to limit their criticism of state institutions, after Egypt’s president warned of a “conspiracy” behind a militant attack last week.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Jerusalem Adding Police Amid Fears of Violence
item.description: A 22-year-old Ecuadorean woman became the second fatality from a collision involving a Palestinian driver who plowed into a group of pedestrians last week.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Brazil Stays With Rousseff as President After Turbulent Campaign
item.description: Dilma Rousseff defeated a centrist challenger, Aécio Neves, in a tumultuous race marked by accusations of corruption, personal insults and heated debates.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil acknowledged the crowd during her acceptance speech at a hotel in Brasília on Sunday.

item.title: Voter Turnout Bolsters Tunisian Hopes for Post-Revolution Stability
item.description: The elections are the second in Tunisia since the popular uprising that set off the Arab Spring. They will bring in a new Parliament and government for a five-year term.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: A man kissing a soldier near a polling station in Tunis on Sunday. The authorities stepped up security before the voting.

item.title: Ukraine President Claims Win for Pro-West Parties
item.description: Official tallies are expected on Monday, but early exit polls suggest the coalition party of President Petro O. Poroshenko was first but falling short of winning a controlling majority.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko held a news conference at a polling station in Kiev on Sunday.

item.title: In Video, Ottawa Gunman Spoke of Political Motives
item.description: While the police did not release the video, an official said it provided persuasive evidence that the attack was motivated by the gunman’s ideology.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: A ceremony at an N.H.L. game in Ottawa on Saturday paid tribute to the Canadian soldiers who were killed last week there and in a separate attack in Quebec.

item.title: Coalition Seeks to Send North Korea to International Court Over Rights Abuses
item.description: Seven months after a groundbreaking report documenting torture and starvation in North Korea, a broad coalition of countries is pushing to refer Pyongyang to the International Criminal Court.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: At the United Nations last week, Kim Song, center, of the North Korean mission, said reports of human rights abuses in his country were a Western plot.

item.title: Laugharne Journal: In Wales, a Toast to Dylan Thomas on His 100th Birthday
item.description: In a country that has long been ill at ease with its hard-living son, Thomas’s granddaughter is trying to refocus public attention on the poet’s work.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gillian Clarke, the national poet of Wales. Some people are trying to refocus attention in Wales on the work of Dylan Thomas. “The soul of his poetry is here,” Ms. Clarke said.

item.title: Conservative Seems Likely to Reach Second Presidential Round in Uruguay
item.description: Luis Lacalle Pou, 41, a leader of the conservative National Party, has mounted a strong challenge to Tabaré Vázquez, a leader of the governing Broad Front.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and MAURICIO RABUFFETTI
item.media:description: Luis Lacalle Pou, left, and Tabaré Vázquez look to succeed President José Mujica.

item.title: Peace Prize Laureates Urge Disclosure on U.S. Torture
item.description: Twelve of President Obama’s fellow Nobel Peace Prize recipients are pushing him to release a Senate report about the C.I.A.'s use of torture after the Sept. 11 attacks.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Using Cash and Pressure, China Builds Its Chip Industry
item.description: The Chinese government is investing billions in domestic chip makers as well as using legal action against multinationals and, experts say, espionage.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A Shanghai factory of the Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation, which has received government help.

item.title: In Cold War, U.S. Spy Agencies Used 1,000 Nazis
item.description: Law enforcement and intelligence leaders believed the ex-Nazis’ intelligence value against the Russians outweighed what one official called “moral lapses” in their service to the Third Reich, according to newly disclosed records.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC LICHTBLAU
item.media:description: Aleksandras Lileikis was a Nazi officer implicated in 60,000 Jews’ deaths. He later worked for the C.I.A. before immigrating.

item.title: As Ebola Spreads, Asia Senses Vulnerability
item.description: Senior officials in China and India have been scrambling to prepare their countries' medical systems to cope with possible cases.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: U.S. and British Troops End Operations in Key Afghan Province
item.description: The handover signified the end of all British operations in the country, as the Afghan Army assumed full control of the bases in Helmand Province.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Ceremonies held by British soldiers and American Marines at Camp Leatherneck and Camp Bastion in Helmand Province in Afghanistan on Sunday.

item.title: International Education: Using Social Media to Shake Up College Fund-Raising
item.description: A successful campaign in Latvia helped triple alumni engagement in just six weeks. Now, universities in the Baltics and beyond are looking to replicate its success.
item.dc:creator: By JENNY MARC
item.media:description: Hardy Rock, a mascot of the Stockholm School of Economics in Latvia.

item.title: Pro-Democracy Movement’s Vote in Hong Kong Abruptly Called Off
item.description: The cancellation of the balloting, which had been intended as a display of unity, exposed tensions over how to sustain the protests.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘The Storm of Reality’: Chinese Poetic Voices From the Lower Tier of Society
item.description: Reacting to a far more complicated, and in some ways tougher, reality than when a last wave of poetry caught public attention in the 1980s, new voices are emerging from China’s working class.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Shangguan Nanhua, with his family in Beijing at the poetry awards, where he won first prize for his anthology "Eights Beats of the Ganzhou Song."

item.title: BelÉm Journal: Daring Fare, From the Amazon’s Mouth to Yours
item.description: A Brazilian chef who passed up the glamour of São Paulo is helping change his country’s cuisine with the help of flavors from the rain forest.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Assassination in Tunisia Draws Spouse Into Politics
item.description: Mbarka Brahmi is campaigning for the seat of her husband, Mohamed Brahmi, the left-wing politician whose assassination by an Islamist extremist group last year sent Tunisia into a crisis.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Oil Gives Kurds a Path to Independence, and Conflict With Baghdad
item.description: Kurdish officials are desperately trying to sell oil abroad, even as the Iraqi government and the United States are blocking their attempts.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
